general: This law makes sure that young people have access to good quality learning and training opportunities so they can get the skills they need to succeed in work. It sets up new organisations to help with this and changes some existing laws to make them more effective. The law also helps to make sure that teachers and other staff in schools are well trained and supported.

series.short: "Apprenticeship Completion Requirements in England and Wales".
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section defines the criteria for completing an apprenticeship in England or Wales.
* Simplified point 2: To complete an apprenticeship, a person must meet certain conditions, such as entering into an apprenticeship agreement, completing a course of training, and meeting specific requirements set out in the apprenticeship framework.
* Simplified point 3: The standard completion conditions for English and Welsh apprenticeships are similar, but there are some differences in the wording and scope of the provisions.
* Simplified point 4: The alternative completion conditions for English and Welsh apprenticeships allow for different types of working arrangements and are specified in regulations made by the relevant authorities.
* Simplified point 5: The section provides for the issue of apprenticeship certificates to those who have completed their apprenticeships.

series.short: "Apprenticeship Certificate Rules in England"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The English certifying authority (Chief Executive of Skills Funding) must issue an apprenticeship certificate to anyone who completes an English apprenticeship program and meets certain conditions.
* Simplified point 2: The authority may issue a certificate even if the framework is no longer recognized if the person met the requirements at the time of their application.
* Simplified point 3: The authority can charge a fee for issuing the certificate, but only if authorized by regulations.
* Simplified point 4: Regulations can also provide for the supply of copies of apprenticeship certificates and authorize the authority to charge a fee for this service.

series.short: "Welsh Apprenticeship Certification Requirements"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Welsh certifying authority must issue an apprenticeship certificate to anyone who completes a Welsh apprenticeship program and meets certain conditions.
* Simplified point 2: The Welsh certifying authority may issue an apprenticeship certificate to someone who has met the requirements of a recognized Welsh apprenticeship framework but did not complete the program.
* Simplified point 3: The Welsh certifying authority can charge a fee for issuing an apprenticeship certificate, and regulations can be made regarding the supply of copies of the certificate.
* Simplified point 4: The Welsh certifying authority is responsible for issuing apprenticeship certificates, and they must comply with directions from the Welsh Ministers and have regard to their guidance.

series.short: Apprenticeship Certificate Requirements in England and Wales
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The contents of an apprenticeship certificate in England and Wales must include the name of the person to whom it is issued, the apprenticeship framework, level, and apprenticeship sector.
* Simplified point 2: The certificate must also state any additional requirements set by regulations.
* Simplified point 3: The "appropriate national authority" responsible for issuing certificates depends on the type of certificate and the location of the apprentice, with the Secretary of State responsible for certificates issued under sections 3 and 4, and the Welsh Ministers responsible for certificates issued under sections 7 and 8.

series.short: Apprenticeship Frameworks Defined
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section defines the meaning of "apprenticeship framework" and explains that it refers to a set of requirements for issuing apprenticeship certificates.
* Simplified point 2: The requirements specified in the framework must be at a particular level and relate to a specific skill, trade, or occupation within an apprenticeship sector.
* Simplified point 3: The section also introduces the concepts of "recognized English framework" and "recognized Welsh framework", which refer to apprenticeship frameworks that have not been withdrawn.
* Simplified point 4: For the purposes of this chapter, an apprenticeship framework is considered to be at the level of the requirements stated in it, and it relates to the apprenticeship sector stated in it.

series.short: "Designation and Oversight of Apprenticeship Frameworks in England"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Apprenticeships, Skills, Children and Learning Act of 2009 gives the Secretary of State the power to designate a person to issue apprenticeship frameworks in England.
* Simplified point 2: The designated person must comply with directions given by the Secretary of State and have regard to guidance given by the Secretary of State when issuing apprenticeship frameworks.
* Simplified point 3: The Secretary of State can amend or revoke the designation of the person issuing the apprenticeship frameworks.
* Simplified point 4: The designated person can only issue apprenticeship frameworks that meet the requirements specified in the specification of apprenticeship standards for England.
* Simplified point 5: Recognition of a recognized English framework may be withdrawn by the English issuing authority or the Secretary of State.
* Simplified point 6: The English issuing authority must publish the apprenticeship frameworks and notify the Chief Executive of Skills Funding of their issue.
* Simplified point 7: A person who withdraws recognition of an apprenticeship framework must publish a notice stating that recognition of the framework has been withdrawn and notify the Chief Executive of Skills Funding of the withdrawal.
* Simplified point 8: The Secretary of State can make orders providing for existing vocational specifications to be treated as if they were apprenticeship frameworks issued under section 14(1).

series.short: "Designation and Oversight of Apprenticeship Frameworks in Wales"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Welsh Ministers have the power to designate a person to issue apprenticeship frameworks in Wales.
* Simplified point 2: The Welsh Ministers can exercise direction and guidance over the designated person.
* Simplified point 3: The designated person must comply with directions and have regard to guidance given by the Welsh Ministers.
* Simplified point 4: The Welsh Ministers can amend or revoke the designation of the person issuing the apprenticeship frameworks.
* Simplified point 5: The Welsh Ministers have the power to withdraw recognition of an apprenticeship framework if it does not meet the specified requirements.
* Simplified point 6: The person issuing the apprenticeship framework must publish the framework and notify the Welsh Ministers of its issue.
* Simplified point 7: A person who withdraws recognition of an apprenticeship framework must publish a notice stating that recognition has been withdrawn and notify the Welsh Ministers.
* Simplified point 8: The Welsh Ministers can make orders to provide for existing vocational specifications to be treated as if they were apprenticeship frameworks issued under section 19(1).

series.short: "UK Government's Power Over Apprenticeship Standards in England"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government has the power to direct the Chief Executive of Skills Funding to prepare and submit a draft specification of apprenticeship standards for England.
* Simplified point 2: The draft specification must be prepared after consulting various stakeholders, including employers, institutions within the further education sector, and providers of training.
* Simplified point 3: The Secretary of State can modify the specification of apprenticeship standards for England by making an order, provided they are satisfied that the modified specification meets certain requirements.
* Simplified point 4: Recognized English frameworks do not cease to be recognized if they do not meet the requirements specified by the specification of apprenticeship standards for England.
* Simplified point 5: The specification of apprenticeship standards for England must specify requirements for recognised English frameworks, including requirements for English certificate requirements, on-the-job training, and off-the-job training.

series.short: "Drafting Apprenticeship Standards for Wales: Government's Sphere of Influence"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Welsh government can create a draft of apprenticeship standards for Wales.
* Simplified point 2: The Welsh government must consult with people they deem appropriate before creating the draft.
* Simplified point 3: Once the draft is created, the Welsh government can make an order to provide that the specification of apprenticeship standards for Wales has effect.
* Simplified point 4: The Welsh government cannot make an order unless they are satisfied that the specification complies with Section 31.
* Simplified point 5: The Welsh government can modify the specification of apprenticeship standards for Wales through an order.
* Simplified point 6: Recognized Welsh frameworks do not cease to be recognized if they no longer meet the requirements specified in the specification of apprenticeship standards for Wales.
* Simplified point 7: The specification of apprenticeship standards for Wales must include requirements for Welsh certificate requirements, on-the-job training, off-the-job training, and the relevant occupational competencies and technical knowledge.

series.short: "England & Wales Apprenticeship Agreements: Legal Requirements & Variations"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section of the legislation outlines the requirements for an apprenticeship agreement in England and Wales.
* Simplified point 2: The agreement must state that it is governed by the law of England and Wales, and must include certain provisions specified in the legislation, such as the duration of the apprenticeship and the terms of the apprentice's employment.
* Simplified point 3: The legislation also provides for variations to the agreement and the status of the apprenticeship agreement as a contract of service.
* Simplified point 4: The section applies to Crown servants and Parliamentary staff, and allows for regulations to modify the provisions of the chapter in relation to these groups.

series.short: "Apprenticeship Inclusions in Education Duty"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This change allows young people in apprenticeships to also be covered under the duty to participate in education or training.
* Simplified point 2: The addition of "or an apprenticeship agreement" in section 2(1)(b) of the Education and Skills Act 2008 includes apprenticeship agreements in the list of eligible programs for the duty to participate in education or training.
* Simplified point 3: The inclusion of "apprenticeship agreement" in the definition of "contract of employment" in section 66(1) of the Education and Skills Act 2008 ensures that apprenticeship agreements are treated similarly to contracts of employment for the purposes of the duty to participate.

series.short: "Apprenticeship Regulations: Skills, Trades, and Occupations Coverage Requirements"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Secretary of State must specify sectors of skill, trade, or occupation for apprenticeships.
* Simplified point 2: These sectors must cover the full range of skills, trades, and occupations.
* Simplified point 3: The legislation defines various terms related to apprenticeships, such as "apprenticeship agreement," "apprenticeship certificate," and "apprenticeship framework."
* Simplified point 4: The legislation specifies the requirements for apprenticeship frameworks, including the need for a recognized English or Welsh framework, and the requirement that the framework include a competencies qualification.
* Simplified point 5: The legislation establishes different authorities for certifying and issuing apprenticeship certificates and frameworks in England and Wales.

series.short: "New Right to Study and Training: Employees Gain Legal Protection for Workplace Learning"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Employment Rights Act 1996 is amended to introduce a new statutory right for employees to make requests to their employers for study and training.
* Simplified point 2: The new right allows employees to make applications to their employers for study and training, and the employer must consider these applications and respond within a certain timeframe.
* Simplified point 3: The applications can be made for any type of study or training that improves the employee's effectiveness in the workplace or the performance of the employer's business.
* Simplified point 4: The study or training can be provided or supervised by the employer or by someone else, and can be undertaken at the employee's home or elsewhere.
* Simplified point 5: Employees have the right to bring complaints to an employment tribunal if their employer fails to comply with the requirements of the new statutory right.
* Simplified point 6: Compensation may be awarded to employees if their employer is found to have breached the new statutory right.

series.short: "Education and Training for Young Adults with Learning Difficulties: A Legal Obligation for Local Education Authorities"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The extract outlines the duty of Local Education Authorities (LEAs) in England to ensure that sufficient suitable education and training is provided to meet the reasonable needs of persons over compulsory school age but under 19, and those subject to learning difficulty assessment.
* Simplified point 2: LEAs must actively encourage participation in education and training by these individuals and encourage employers to participate in providing training.
* Simplified point 3: The extract also covers the power of LEAs to require further education institutions to provide education to named individuals, and the duty to provide education suitable to the needs of individuals with learning difficulties.

series.short: The Apprenticeships, Skills, Children and Learning Act 2009: Education Entitlement for Young Adults
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Apprenticeships, Skills, Children and Learning Act 2009 requires local education authorities in England to provide courses of study for individuals aged 16-18.
* Simplified point 2: Individuals can choose between the "core entitlement" (study in math, English, and information technology) or the "additional entitlement" (study in other areas specified by the Secretary of State).
* Simplified point 3: Local education authorities must ensure that courses of study are available within or outside their area, and they must have regard to any guidance given by the Secretary of State.
* Simplified point 4: The core entitlement is satisfied if a course of study in each chosen core subject is made available to the individual, while the additional entitlement is satisfied if a course of study in an additional entitlement area is made available.
* Simplified point 5: If an individual does not begin a course of study before turning 19, their entitlement ceases.

series.short: "Education and Training Support for Individuals with Learning Difficulties in England"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This clause allows local education authorities in England to provide boarding accommodations for individuals over compulsory school age but under 25 who are subject to learning difficulty assessments, in order to support their education and training.
* Simplified point 2: The clause permits the local education authorities to secure the provision of boarding accommodations both within and outside their area, and it doesn't matter who provides the education or training.
* Simplified point 3: The clause defines "education" and "training" as having the same meanings as in Section 15ZA of the act.

series.short: "Work Experience Opportunities for Young People and Those with Learning Difficulties in England"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This clause allows local education authorities in England to provide work experience opportunities for individuals between the ages of 14-18 and those with learning difficulties up to the age of 25.
* Simplified point 2: The clause requires local education authorities to encourage participation in work experience programs for eligible individuals and to encourage employers to participate in providing work experiences for these individuals.

series.short: "Education Rights for Young Offenders: Ensuring Suitable Learning Opportunities"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Apprenticeships, Skills, Children and Learning Act 2009 requires local education authorities to provide suitable education to children subject to youth detention in their area.
* Simplified point 2: The education provided must meet the reasonable needs of the children based on their ages, abilities, and aptitudes, and take into account any special educational needs or learning difficulties they may have.
* Simplified point 3: The education provided must also enable the children to complete programs of study or training they have begun, and be comparable to education they would receive if they were attending a school or institution implementing a relevant curriculum.
* Simplified point 4: Local education authorities must have regard to any guidance issued by the Secretary of State in England or the Welsh Ministers in Wales when performing their duty to provide education to children subject to youth detention.
* Simplified point 5: The Act applies to children over compulsory school age but under 19 who are subject to youth detention, and provides for the core entitlement and additional entitlement to be satisfied in relation to these children.

series.short: "Youth Detention Law Change: Limited Legal Protection for Certain Detainees"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This law change allows certain people who are detained in youth accommodations to not have the same legal protections as other detainees.
* Simplified point 2: The law change specifically targets people who are detained in accommodations that are not considered "youth detention accommodations" and are not in young offender institutions.
* Simplified point 3: The law change also excludes children and young people who are being kept in accommodations for the purpose of restricting their liberty from being considered as detained in pursuance of an order made by a court.
* Simplified point 4: The law change only applies to people who are detained in accommodations that are not wholly or mainly used for the detention of people aged 18 and over.

series.short: "Education Provisions for Detained Children Outlined in UK Law"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Apprenticeships, Skills, Children and Learning Act 2009 outlines provisions for detained children's education.
* Simplified point 2: Detained children are entitled to receive education and training while in custody, and the act specifies how these provisions should be implemented.
* Simplified point 3: The act requires local education authorities to provide special educational provision for detained children with special needs, and allows for the supply of goods and services to support this provision.
* Simplified point 4: The host authority must assess the literacy and numeracy skills of detained children as soon as possible after their detainment, and make arrangements for appropriate education or training based on the results of this assessment.

series.short: "Education Information Sharing Between Authorities for Detained Individuals"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The provision of information between local education authorities regarding detained individuals' education and training.
* Simplified point 2: The requirement for local education authorities to provide information to the host authority upon request, including assessment reports and statements of special educational needs.
* Simplified point 3: The notification requirements for local education authorities when a detained individual is released from detention, including the transfer of information to the home authority and the host authority.

series.short: "Education Authority Guidelines for Detaining Youths"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The local education authority must follow guidance issued by the appropriate national authority when performing their functions under this chapter.
* Simplified point 2: The appropriate national authority is either the Secretary of State for Education in England or the Welsh Ministers in Wales.
* Simplified point 3: "Beginning of the detention" refers to the start of a period of detention in relevant youth accommodation, regardless of whether it's part of a continuous period.
* Simplified point 4: "Detained person" means a person who is currently being detained in relevant youth accommodation.
* Simplified point 5: "Home authority" refers to the local education authority responsible for a looked-after child, while "host authority" refers to the local education authority where the child is currently detained.
* Simplified point 6: "Looked after child" means a child who is being cared for by a local authority under the Children Act 1989.
* Simplified point 7: "Young person" includes anyone aged 18 or under.

series.short: "Education Notification Requirements for Detained Youth"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This law requires local education authorities to be notified when a child or young person is detained in a youth institution.
* Simplified point 2: The notification must be made as soon as possible after the child or young person is detained, and must include information about the location of the detention.
* Simplified point 3: The purpose of this law is to ensure that local education authorities are aware of the educational needs of children and young people who are detained in youth institutions, so that they can provide appropriate support and services.

series.short: "Education Rights for Detained Youth: Law Ensures Continuity of Statements"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This law states that when a child or young person with special educational needs is released from detention, their educational statements should be transferred to the new local education authority responsible for them after release.
* Simplified point 2: The law ensures that the educational statements are maintained even if the child was detained in different accommodations, and it doesn't matter if the detention was pursuant to a single order or multiple orders.
* Simplified point 3: The law requires the old local education authority to transfer the statement to the new authority, and the statement is then treated as being maintained by the new authority under Section 324 of the Education Act 1996.
* Simplified point 4: The law also specifies that reviews of the child's educational needs should take into account the fact that they have been subject to a detention order and were detained in relevant youth accommodation before their release.

series.short: "UK Transportation Policy for Students in Sixth Form Age: Legislative Requirements and Guidance"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government has enacted legislation requiring local education authorities to provide transportation for students in England, particularly those in sixth form age.
* Simplified point 2: The law mandates that local education authorities must prepare a statement outlining the transportation arrangements for students in sixth form age, including the time frame for publishing the statement and the process for revising it.
* Simplified point 3: The legislation covers transportation policies for young adults with learning difficulties, including the requirement for local education authorities to consult with various stakeholders before preparing the transportation policy statement.
* Simplified point 4: The law empowers the Secretary of State to issue guidance on sections 508F and 508G of the Education Act 1996 regarding transportation arrangements for young adults with learning difficulties.
* Simplified point 5: Local education authorities can revise the transportation policy statement if a complaint is filed against them, and they must publish the revised statement and a description of the revision as soon as possible.
* Simplified point 6: The Secretary of State has the discretion to exercise powers under sections 496 to 497A of the Education Act 1996 to prevent unreasonable exercises of functions, etc., in response to a complaint made to them.

series.short: "Local Education Authority Powers for Non-Maintained Schools"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Local Education Authorities (LEAs) can make arrangements for providing education at non-maintained schools.
* Simplified point 2: The powers of LEAs to assist and arrange provision of education at non-maintained schools continue to be effective even after certain provisions of the School Standards and Framework Act 1998 have ceased to have effect.

series.short: "Establishment of the Young People's Learning Agency for England"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Young People's Learning Agency for England (YPLA) is established as a separate legal entity responsible for performing functions related to learning in England.
* Simplified point 2: The YPLA has exclusive jurisdiction over its functions in England, except for certain exceptions specified in sections 68-70.
* Simplified point 3: Schedule 3 provides additional details regarding the YPLA's operations.

series.short: "Financial Support for Youth Education and Training Programs"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Young People's Learning Agency (YPLA) provides financial resources to individuals and organizations offering education and training programs for young people between the ages of 13 and 19, as well as those up to age 25 with learning difficulties.
* Simplified point 2: The YPLA secures funding through various means, including direct provision, arranging for others to provide resources, and making arrangements for joint funding with other parties.
* Simplified point 3: Financial resources provided by the YPLA can be subject to certain conditions, such as information and operational conditions, repayment conditions, and means testing.
* Simplified point 4: The YPLA performs assessments of the performance of providers of funded education and training, and uses the results of these assessments to inform its decision-making regarding funding.
* Simplified point 5: The YPLA prohibits charging for the provision of relevant education or training, except in cases where regulations specify otherwise.

series.short: "Education and Training for Young Offenders: Ensuring Appropriate Support"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Young People's Learning Agency (YPLA) can ensure that young people receive appropriate education and training after they turn 16, even if they are no longer in formal schooling.
* Simplified point 2: The YPLA can provide education and training for young people who are subject to youth detention, and must consider the actions of local education authorities in performing their duties under the Education Act 1996.
* Simplified point 3: If the YPLA determines that a local education authority is failing or likely to fail in their duty to provide education and training, the YPLA can give directions to the authority to ensure the provision of suitable education and training.

series.short: "Education and Training Services for Young People: Regulations and Consent Requirements"
series.text:
* The Young People's Learning Agency (YPLA) can provide services and assistance to certain organizations and individuals related to education and training. These services can include providing accommodations, managing facilities, procuring goods and services, and more.
* The YPLA can make arrangements with permitted recipients for the provision of these services. Permitted recipients include government agencies, educational institutions, and other organizations involved in education and training.
* Before making arrangements with permitted recipients, the YPLA must obtain consent from the appropriate national authority, depending on the location where the education or training is being provided.
* The YPLA can also participate in arrangements made by the Secretary of State, Welsh Ministers, or Scottish Ministers under the Employment and Training Act 1973 for assisting persons to select, train for, obtain, and retain employment.
* Consent must be obtained from the appropriate authorities before making such arrangements.

series.short: "Education and Training Regulation: Young People's Learning Agency's Powers and Duties"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Young People's Learning Agency (YPLA) can conduct research and develop programs related to education and training.
* Simplified point 2: The YPLA must provide information and advice to the Secretary of State upon request, and can provide information to other people designated by the Secretary of State.
* Simplified point 3: The YPLA must establish systems for collecting information to make informed decisions about education and training.
* Simplified point 4: The YPLA must issue guidance to local education authorities about their duties, and must consult with them before doing so.
* Simplified point 5: The YPLA must prepare a statement of its policy regarding the exercise of its intervention powers, keep the statement under review, and revise it as necessary.
* Simplified point 6: The YPLA must send a copy of the statement to the Secretary of State for approval and publish it as soon as possible after approval.
* Simplified point 7: The YPLA must have regard to its latest published statement when exercising its intervention powers.
* Simplified point 8: The Secretary of State can confer supplementary functions on the YPLA through an order.

series.short: "Government Oversight of Youth Education: Secretary of State Directives for Young People's Learning Agency"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Secretary of State can issue directions to the Young People's Learning Agency (YPLA) regarding the agency's objectives, time limits, and management.
* Simplified point 2: The Secretary of State can also give directions to the YPLA if the agency has failed to fulfill a duty or has acted unreasonably.
* Simplified point 3: The Secretary of State can provide guidance to the YPLA on how to perform its functions, including consultation with certain groups of people.
* Simplified point 4: The YPLA must follow any guidance provided by the Secretary of State when performing its functions.

series.short: The Apprenticeships, Skills, Children and Learning Act 2009: Academy Arrangements and Information Sharing
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Apprenticeships, Skills, Children and Learning Act 2009 allows the Secretary of State to require the Young People's Learning Agency (YPLA) to enter into agreements with the Secretary of State for the provision of Academy arrangements.
* Simplified point 2: Academy arrangements are agreements between the YPLA and the Secretary of State for the YPLA to exercise specified Academy functions on behalf of the Secretary of State. These functions relate to Academies, city technology colleges, or city colleges for the technology of the arts.
* Simplified point 3: The Secretary of State can make grants to the YPLA for the purposes of any functions that are or may be conferred or imposed on the YPLA under Academy arrangements.
* Simplified point 4: The Secretary of State and the YPLA can share information for the purpose of enabling or facilitating the exercise of any relevant function. A "relevant function" includes a function conferred or imposed on the YPLA under the arrangements, as well as functions of the Secretary of State, relevant Academies, or any other person exercisable in connection with a function conferred or imposed on the YPLA.

series.short: "Education and Training Jurisdiction of the Youth Purpose Learning and Apprenticeships Act"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section defines the scope of the Youth Purpose Learning and Apprenticeships (YPLA) Act's jurisdiction regarding education and training for young people.
* Simplified point 2: The YPLA has authority over education and training for individuals aged 14 to 19 and those aged 19 to 25 who have learning difficulties.
* Simplified point 3: The term "education" in this context encompasses both full-time and part-time instruction.
* Simplified point 4: The definition of "training" in this section includes various types of vocational, social, physical, and recreational training, as well as apprenticeship training.
* Simplified point 5: The YPLA's jurisdiction does not extend to adults who are subject to detention, as defined in Section 121(4) of the Act.

series.short: "Appointment and Functions of the Chief Executive of Skills Funding in England"
series.text:
* The Chief Executive of Skills Funding will be appointed by the Secretary of State.
* The Chief Executive will perform functions related to England only, except as specified in sections 107, 108, or 109.
* Schedule 4 provides additional provisions regarding the Chief Executive.

series.short: "UK Government Delegates Apprenticeship Responsibilities to Other Organizations or Individuals"
series.text:
* The UK government can delegate some of its responsibilities related to apprenticeships to other organizations or individuals through the Apprenticeship Functions.
* This delegation can include tasks such as managing apprenticeship certificates, specifying apprenticeship standards, providing apprenticeship training, and offering advice and assistance to the Secretary of State.
* The Secretary of State has the authority to direct the Chief Executive to arrange for these apprenticeship functions to be performed by a designated person, who must report to the Secretary of State on their progress.
* The designated person must consent to being appointed, and the arrangements can allow for sub-delegation of tasks to other individuals or organizations.
* Regulations can modify or exclude certain provisions of the law when it comes to these apprenticeship functions, depending on the situation.

series.short: "Apprenticeship Training Regulations in England"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Apprenticeships, Skills, Children and Learning Act of 2009 allows the Chief Executive to provide apprenticeship training for individuals between the ages of 16 and 18, as well as those up to age 25 with learning difficulties.
* Simplified point 2: The Chief Executive must consider factors like the individual's age, ability, aptitude, learning difficulties, and the quality of training when providing apprenticeship training.
* Simplified point 3: The Chief Executive must prioritize diversifying apprenticeship training options, increasing opportunities for choice, and fulfilling the duty to participate in education or training for those covered by Part 1 of the Education and Skills Act of 2008.
* Simplified point 4: Local education authorities in England can make determinations about apprenticeship training, and the Chief Executive must collaborate with these authorities to ensure the provision of appropriate training.
* Simplified point 5: Employers are encouraged to participate in and contribute to the costs of training for individuals within section 83(1)(a) or (b) of the act.

series.short: "Education and Training Opportunities for Adults in Detention Centers in the UK"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government requires the Chief Executive to provide reasonable educational facilities for people aged 19 or older, including those in adult detention.
* Simplified point 2: These facilities should be appropriate for each individual's needs and include both full-time and part-time education and training options.
* Simplified point 3: The Chief Executive must also ensure that courses leading to recognized qualifications are available and free of charge to eligible students.
* Simplified point 4: Regulations can specify conditions for receiving free education, such as possessing certain qualifications or completing specific courses.
* Simplified point 5: The Chief Executive has discretion to determine how to best use resources to encourage diversity and increase choices for individuals.
* Simplified point 6: Employers are encouraged to participate in education and training programs for eligible individuals and contribute to associated costs.

series.short: "Apprenticeship Offer Guidelines"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The apprenticeship offer requires the Chief Executive to ensure that apprenticeship places are available in sufficient numbers and variety for all eligible individuals.
* Simplified point 2: The apprenticeship offer requires individuals to hold specific qualifications and be available for employment under an apprenticeship agreement.
* Simplified point 3: The apprenticeship offer is only available to individuals who are within certain age ranges and meet specific criteria.
* Simplified point 4: The apprenticeship offer can be suspended in certain areas for a period of up to two years.
* Simplified point 5: The Secretary of State has the power to amend the requirements of the apprenticeship offer.

series.short: "UK Education Funding Law: Providing Financial Resources for Training and Development"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government created the Apprenticeships, Skills, Children and Learning Act of 2009 to provide financial resources to individuals and organizations offering education and training.
* Simplified point 2: The law allows the Chief Executive to secure funding for educational initiatives, including apprenticeship programs, and provides guidelines for how these funds should be used.
* Simplified point 3: The Chief Executive can enter into agreements with authorized parties to offer services related to locating apprenticeship positions, promoting progression from Level 2 to Level 3 apprenticeships, and giving counsel and help regarding apprenticeships.
* Simplified point 4: The Chief Executive can collaborate with the Secretary of State to provide services related to job and training, such as accommodation and other amenities, and procuring or helping to procure commodities and services for usage by a permitted recipient.
* Simplified point 5: The Chief Executive can conduct studies and create systems for gathering data to ensure that choices concerning education and training are based on reliable information.
* Simplified point 6: The Secretary of State can assign additional responsibilities to the Chief Executive through an executive order. These extra duties must be directly tied to the provision of facilities for education or training inside the Chief Executive's purview.
